body:
Use the `--acd-upload-wait-time` flag to reduce that time limit.

It really shouldn't be waiting on a 429 error though - I need to fix that.

rename.from: Lots of failures slowdown syncs. Configurable waits?
rename.to: acd: Stop waiting for files to appear when we got a 429 error

body:
I've fixed this here: http://pub.rclone.org/v1.33-19-g83ba597%CE%B2/

Please re-open if you find any problems with it

issue.title: on ACD. large files give 504 error. The files appears to be on ACD. Rclone redoes the upload.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
on ACD. large files give 504 error. The files appears to be on ACD. Rclone redoes the upload.

This seems to happen roughly 100% of the time on files of size 10-50GB that I've tested it on so far.
The end result of some files is that they upload fine the first try. Some files will 504 three times and then rclone will exit (it only retries the command three times).... after the third time the file is just on ACD... as far as I can tell all three uploads worked perfectly. While the error message appears almost always on these files the unneeded repetitions only happens maybe 10-20% of the time? or looking over my test files it seems the unneeded repetitions happen always on files greater than 31gb and on files 10-31gb the error message appears but then in the second round the check realizes it doesn't need to repeat and so doesn't.

I'm on ethernet not wireless which is why I didn't just post in this thread: https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/183

edit: here's a quote of an exact error of this type:
2015/12/24 20:59:52 gigatribe stuff 1.5.7z.003: Failed to copy: HTTP code 504: "
504 GATEWAY_TIMEOUT", no response body

body: @ncw I see the opposite behavior, where rclone _should_ wait for the file to appear on 429 errors. So it re-uploads file when not needed on the latest beta (v1.33-56-gd42b386Î²).
@felixbuenemann I think if amazon give you a 429 the file hasn't been uploaded properly - what makes you think otherwise?

Here's an example log, where the file appeared after the 429 error (I aborted the re-upload with Ctrl+C and checked the ACD Web UI to confirm the file was already there):

```
2016/10/14 08:09:46 
Transferred:   217.666 GBytes (491.589 kBytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                30
Transferred:           39
Elapsed time:  128h58m7.7s
Transferring:
 *                                   bigfile.img: 99% done. avg:  499.9, cur:  500.7 kByte/s. ETA: 5s

2016/10/14 08:10:17 pacer: Rate limited, sleeping for 300.159908ms (1 consecutive low level retries)
2016/10/14 08:10:17 pacer: low level retry 1/1 (error HTTP code 429: "429 Too Many Requests", reponse body: {"logref":"df9ed002-91d4-11e6-8484-fbfc7cdd26ec","message":"Rate exceeded","code":""}
)
2016/10/14 08:10:17 bigfile.img: Received error: HTTP code 429: "429 Too Many Requests", reponse body: {"logref":"df9ed002-91d4-11e6-8484-fbfc7cdd26ec","message":"Rate exceeded","code":""}
 - low level retry 1/10
2016/10/14 08:10:17 pacer: Resetting sleep to minimum 20ms on success
2016/10/14 08:10:46 
Transferred:   217.683 GBytes (491.563 kBytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                30
Transferred:           39
Elapsed time:  128h59m7.7s
Transferring:
 *                                   bigfile.img:  0% done. avg:  511.6, cur:  530.1 kByte/s. ETA: 2h23m36s
```

So far the only error I've seen where the file did not appear after the transfer went to 100% was 500 errors (it did appear on 504 errors).

I guess the differences between the two cases would be if the error occurs at the beginning of the data transfer or after it has finished.

> I think maybe getting the timing more accurate and reverting the above patch might be the best solution.

Yes, that seems like a reasonable solution, because waiting mostly hurts upload of many small files, which would no longer enter the wait loop with the dynamic wait time.

OK here is my latest attempt to fix this problem.  See below for changed docs.

http://pub.rclone.org/v1.33-66-g2e20a0f-acd-timeout%CE%B2/

Any feedback very welcome, with suggestions for the default parameter values.  In my tests I successfully uploaded a range of file sizes up to 15 GB.  The tests weren't successful before I introduced the extra 2m sleep.

#### --acd-upload-wait-time=TIME, --acd-upload-wait-per-gb=TIME, --acd-upload-wait-limit=TIME

Sometimes Amazon Drive gives an error when a file has been fully
uploaded but the file appears anyway after a little while.  This
happens sometimes for files over 1GB in size and nearly every time for
files bigger than 10GB. These parameters control the time rclone waits
for the file to appear.

If the upload took less than `--acd-upload-wait-limit` (default 60s),
then we go ahead an upload it again as that will be quicker.

We wait `--acd-upload-wait-time` (default 2m) for the file to appear,
with an additional `--acd-upload-wait-per-gb` (default 30s) per GB of
the uploaded file.

These values were determined empirically by observing lots of uploads
of big files for a range of file sizes.

Upload with the `-v` flag to see more info about what rclone is doing
in this situation.

I've switched to the new build and am uploading a folder with lots of file in the 10GB range with the default settings. I've set stats delay to 15m so I can see what happened after a couple of days.

Btw. it would be great if rclone could print the filename of the file it is about to upload once, so one doesn't have to wait for the stats delay to see which file is currently uploaded.

I've merged this to master here: http://beta.rclone.org/v1.33-76-g5b83270/ (will be uploaded in 15-30 mins)

Let me know if you find any problems and I'll re-open the ticket if you do!
